entry.title: Combined summary - Presenting a BIP for Shamir's Secret Sharing of Bitcoin private keys
entry.summary: The conversation revolves around Bitcoin Improvement Proposals (BIPs), covering various technical details of their implementation. One of the topics discussed is threshold ECDSA with BIP32, which involves base58 encoding and big integer arithmetic. Additionally, secret sharing and the use of fields in BIPs are also discussed. The participants express different opinions on the benefits of using GF(2^8) for byte-wise operations and processing secrets of any size.Some of the individuals in the conversation emphasize the importance of simplicity and straightforwardness in implementing these proposals, while others argue for efficiency and scalability. The discussion also touches on the concept of testnet and how it was not created by Satoshi, but rather exists for public testing with multiple people and services. It serves as a public live fire environment where grey hats can try out their attacks while minimizing damage.The writer expresses concern about any private key secret sharing scheme that is not compatible with threshold ECDSA, stating that it would be just another redundant specification. Finally, the discussion touches on different field choices, including the field order (p), which is how all arithmetic already works in Bitcoin. Overall, the conversation demonstrates the complexity and diversity of perspectives involved in improving the Bitcoin protocol.
